div.head: Structural Evolution in Nd 1-x Sr x CoO 3-δ Perovskites
div.p: We have examined the structural evolution in Nd 1-x Sr x CoO 3-δ perovskites as a function of Sr-doping and temperature. Preliminary structural analysis of data collected at 298 K, reveals three distinct phases: 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.4: orthorhombic Pnma (√2a p ×2a p ×√2a p ; where "a p " is the dimensions of the basic perovskite unit); 0.5 ≤ x ≤ 0.7: a biphasic region; and a simple cubic (Pm-3m) phase for 0.8 ≤ x ≤ 0.9. The structural evolution of the "biphasic" composition Nd 0.4 Sr 0.6 CoO 3-δ as a function of temperature between 80 K and 750 K reveals that a single (simple cubic Pm-3m) phase is present above 600K (Figure 1). 80 K 200 300 400 500 The Ho 1-x Sr x CoO 3-δ family of compounds forms single phase samples for compositions x> 0.6. Our previous studies indicated that for 0.6 < x ≤ 0.9, a 2a p ×2a p ×4a p tetragonal (I4/mmm) superstructure is formed; while the x = 0.95 composition crystallises with a a p ×a p ×2a p tetragonal (P4/mmm) superstructure at 295 K.

We collected diffraction patterns for Ho 1-x Sr x CoO 3-δ for x = 0.7, 0.8, and 0.9 at temperatures ranging from 80 K to 700 K. At room temperature, Ho 0.30 Sr 0.70 CoO 3-δ and Ho 0.10 Sr 0.90 CoO 3-δ showed tetragonal (I4/mmm: 2a p ×2a p ×4a p ) perovskite superstructures. Data for Ho 0.20 Sr 0.80 CoO 3-δ showed an additional structural modulation, leading to a larger orthorhombic (Amam: 4√2a p ×2√2a p ×4a p ) cell (see below).

Both samples of Ho 0.3 Sr 0.7 CoO 3-δ and Ho 0.2 Sr 0.8 CoO 3-δ showed structural transitions as a function of temperature. Ho 0.1 Sr 0.9 CoO 3-δ showed only thermal expansion with increasing temperature.

Structural Modulations in Ln 0.2 Sr 0.8 CoO 3-δ (Ln = Dy 3+ , Ho 3+ , Er 3+ and Tm 3+ ) Perovskites During experiment HE-1716, we noted additional splittings and superstructure reflections associated with the composition Y 0.20 Sr 0.80 CoO 3-δ . At odds with the structure reported in the literature for this composition (tetragonal, I4/mmm: 2a p ×2a p ×4a p ), we determined the cell to be a larger orthorhombic structure.

We measured the diffraction profiles for Ln 1-x Sr x CoO 3-δ (Ln = Gd-Tm; x = 0.8) at room temperature and observed an additional structural modulation associated with Ln/Sr and O/vacancy ordering for Ln = Dy-Tm.

As in the case of Ho 0.20 Sr 0.80 CoO 3-δ , structures have been able to be indexed using the orthorhombic (Amam: 4√2a p ×2√2a p ×4a p ) cell. The additional contrast between the rare earth ions (Ln 3+ ) and Sr 2+ (compared to isoelectronic Y 3+ and Sr 2+ used in our previous experiment) enabled us to successfully index this phase.
Examination of Tm 0.20 Sr 0.80 CoO 3-δ , as a function of temperature revealed an intermediate phase between room temperature and the high temperature tetragonal (Figure 2).
Structure solution and refinements for each of these phases is continuing.
